Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) (proximate cause principles);
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: See Restatement (Second) of Torts §§ 282, 283; Restatement (Second) of Torts § 314A (duty to invitees and entrants); see generally Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) (proximate cause principles); Massachusetts General Laws and applicable Massachusetts decisions recognize and apply these principles to premises liability and supervision claims.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: Palsgraf does not deal with the Restatement provisions or Massachusetts premises liability directly, but it is accurately cited here only for its general discussion of proximate cause principles. Cardozo’s opinion is a foundational torts case on the relational nature of duty and the scope of foreseeable risk, which underlies modern proximate cause analysis applied in premises and supervision cases. Thus, using Palsgraf as a “see generally” citation for proximate cause principles is appropriate and supported by the opinion’s reasoning.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: “The risk reasonably to be perceived defines the duty to be obeyed, and risk imports relation; it is risk to another or to others within the range of apprehension… Negligence, like risk, is thus a term of relation. Negligence is not a tort unless it results in the commission of a wrong, and the commission of a wrong imports the violation of a right… The law of causation, remote or proximate, is thus foreign to the case before us.”

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 260, \u00a7 2A..proposition: The Massachusetts statute of limitations for personal injury actions is three (3) years from the date of injury.
